clip.title: "Yesterday the Pope published his long awaited Encyclical on the environment." - Rt Rev Lord Harries - 19/06/15

synopses.short: Thought for the Day
synopses.medium: Thought for the Day
synopses.long: Good morning. One of my favourite Stanley Spencer paintings shows Jesus throwing himself on the ground, on all fours, in order to place his eyes and nose within a few inches of some field daisies. It is Spencer’s imaginative way of picturing those wonderful words “Consider the lilies of the field, not even Solomon in all his glory was clothed like one of these” And that is just one of the many sayings of Jesus which reveal his great love for the natural world. Yesterday the Pope published his long awaited Encyclical on the environment. He sees the relationship each one of us has with creation as a profoundly spiritual matter. It is not just about economics, or saving the most vulnerable communities in the world, crucial though that is, it is about getting our whole relationship with nature and one another right. It is important not to be sentimental about nature-rural poverty is a terrible thing, which has blighted human history and from which billions still suffer. Technological developments, with all their downside, can lift people out of that backbreaking toil. But our ancestors knew that they had to treat nature with respect for its own unfolding rhythms, working in partnership with it, coaxing it rather than plundering it. Indeed any landscape you look at will be the result of a respectful interaction between humans and natural processes over many thousands of years. That is very different from the kind of ruthless exploitation or disregard for the consequences of our behaviour that has characterised a fair amount of our behaviour over the last two centuries. That is why a key Christian concept is that we are stewards of the earth. It is not ours to do what just we like with. We are accountable-to one another and to future generations -accountable both for the economic policies of our governments and our own consumer habits. Most human beings find refreshment through nature, whether it is just looking at a flower, walking under a tree, sitting on the grass during a lunchtime break or looking up at the sky to see the swifts swooping and darting. Many experience this as something spiritual. A key imperative in the Encyclical is our shared responsibility to safeguard it for others. We are blessed with a good earth; it nourishes and sustains us. We have a responsibility to ensure that those who come after us continue to have that blessing. The Encyclical is hard hitting about the complacency and lack of will in both Government policies and our own lifestyles in the developed world but is not finally pessimistic. As it says. “Humanity still has the ability to work together in building our common home” We are still capable of “choosing what is good and making a new start.”

clip.title: Steve Breed: When goal sent Torquay United's new CEO 'nuts'

synopses.short: When goal sent Torquay's CEO 'nuts'
synopses.medium: When goal sent Torquay's CEO 'nuts'
synopses.long: Torquay United's new chief executive Steve Breed's goes 'nuts' on BBC Radio Devon when Luke Young blasts in a winner against Wrexham.

clip.title: Lizzie Armitstead: Crash 'could have been worse'

synopses.short: British cyclist is out of Women's tour following finishing line crash with a photographer
synopses.medium: British cyclist, Lizzie Armitstead, said she feels "miserable", after a crash with a photographer forced her out of the Women’s Tour, where she was the favourite to win the race.
synopses.long: British cyclist, Lizzie Armitstead, said she feels "miserable", after a crash with a photographer at the finishing line in Aviva Women’s Tour of Britain, forced her out of the rest of the tour, where she was the favourite to win the race. She had won the race in a sprint finish and had raised her arms in celebration before putting them back on the handlebars and veering left into a group of photographers. However, Armitstead admitted the crash "could have been much worse" despite spraining her wrist and doing damage to her leg, but her first instinct was to "worry about the photographer" she had crashed in to. Her father, John, had not heard about the crash until his daughter's manager rang him at work, and said watching the incident was "not good for the blood pressure". This clip is originally from 5 live Daily on Friday 19 June 2015.

synopses.short: The former Home Secretary speaks to John Humphrys about his life in politics.
synopses.medium: The former Home Secretary speaks to John Humphrys about his life in politics.
synopses.long: Almost 45 years since he was first elected to Sheffield City Council, David Blunkett has announced he's stepping down as MP. The former Home Secretary speaks to John Humphrys about his life in politics, the affair that cost him his post and succeeding as a blind man in Westminster. Producer: Katie Prescott. Editor: Jamie Angus. This was originally broadcast on 22 June 2014.

synopses.long: After weeks of violence in Burundi over the president's controversial bid for a third term, two BBC journalists from the country - Prime Ndikumagenge and Robert Misigaro - pick the music that defines Burundi, past and present. It ranges from ancient inanga harp music to contemporary reggae.

clip.title: Cyprus 'abduction attempt': Should we be worried?

synopses.short: Child snatching gangs: what is the real story?
synopses.medium: Experts believe "misconceptions" about how regularly children are snatched by strangers can be "unhealthy" for parents.
synopses.long: Experts believe "misconceptions" about how regularly children are abducted can lead to overprotective parents. Delphine Moralis, Secretary General of Missing Children Europe, said that it was important to "put things in perspective" and understand that cases of child abduction are "extremely rare". Charlie Hedges, an independent advisor who works with organisations which search for missing and abducted children agreed that parents should not be "overly concerned". Their comments came after British holidaymakers staying at a complex in Cyprus became suspicious of people who they claimed were deliberately watching or attempting to lead young children away from the hotel. This clip is originally from 5 live Breakfast on June 19 2015.

clip.title: Why print copies of Wikipedia?

synopses.short: Wikipedia would made an encyclopaedia of 7,473 volumes and 5.4 million pages
synopses.medium: Wikipedia would made an encyclopaedia of 7,473 volumes and 5.4 million pages
synopses.long: Traditionally encyclopaedias stored knowledge, in dozens of neat volumes. But the sum of knowledge available digitally on Wikipedia is much larger. Artist Michael Mandiberg is printing out parts of Wikipedia to show just how much knowledge it holds: that’s around 7,473 volumes and 5.4 million pages. The exhibition is about to open at the Denny Gallery in New York. (Photo: Spines of the printed Wikipedia. Credit: Michael Mandiberg and Denny Gallery NYC)

Astronomer Dr Lucie Green, addictions researcher Dr Sally Marlow and Chief Executive of the BBSRC, Professor Jackie Hunter, talk about their experience and perspective of sexism in the lab. First broadcast on BBC Inside Science, 18 June 2015.

clip.title: 'It isn't ugly' - Rogers on Robin Hood Gardens

synopses.short: Lord Rogers: Controversial brutalist housing estate should be saved.
synopses.medium: Brutalist housing development should be designated as a building of special architectural interest, said Lord Rogers.
synopses.long: Lord Rogers has called on the government to designate a controversial brutalist housing development in London's east end as a building of special architectural interest. Robin Hood Gardens, which was finished in 1972, has been threatened with demolition. "The building is, without doubt, the best piece of social and architectural thinking in the last 50 years," said Lord Rogers, whose work includes the Pompidou Centre in Paris, London's Millennium Dome, Cardiff's Senedd and the European Court of Human Rights building in Strasbourg. "We will look back on it as a major piece." The building was designed by Alison and Peter Smithson, the inventors of the New Brutalist style of the 1950s.

clip.title: 'He was born with a nervous breakdown'

synopses.short: Pierre Berge on the brilliance of Yves Saint Laurent
synopses.medium: Pierre Berge on the brilliance of Yves Saint Laurent
synopses.long: A major exhibition about on the life and work of Yves Saint Laurent opens at the Bowes Museum in County Durham next month. Ahead of it, Rebecca Jones spoke to Pierre Berge, who was Saint Laurent's lover and business partner for 50 years. Speaking of the relentless pressures of the fashion industry and resulting alcohol and drug addictions, Berg said: "He was born with a nervous breakdown."

clip.title: Chibok Girls Living in US

synopses.short: Journalist for Cosmopolitan magazine talks about their adjustment to life in Oregon
synopses.medium: The four Nigerian girls who escaped Boko Haram kidnappers in 2014, are now living in Oregon. Cosmopolitan magazine's Abigail Pesta has been spending time with them.
synopses.long: More than 200 Nigerian school girls, kidnapped more than a year ago by Boko Haram militants, are still missing. But four of them who managed to escape are now living in the US state of Oregon. Cosmopolitan magazine's Abigail Pesta has been spending time with Mercy, Sarah, Deborah, and Grace. She tells Dan about how they've adjusted to their new lives (Mercy, Sarah, and Deborah in Oregon. Photo credit: Christopher Wahl/Cosmopolitan.)

clip.title: Letter recounts 1919 scuttling of German fleet at Scapa Flow.

synopses.short: 'The grimmest incident of the whole war'
synopses.medium: Newly found letter recounts 'grimmest incident of the whole war'
synopses.long: A new eyewitness account has emerged of the German fleet being scuppered at Scapa Flow in the Orkneys in 1919.

clip.title: 'The grimmest incident of the whole war'

synopses.short: 'The grimmest incident of the whole war'
synopses.medium: 'The grimmest incident of the whole war'
synopses.long: The discovery of a letter offers a rare and frank personal account of the scuttling of the German fleet in Scapa Flow in the Orkneys Islands in 1919. In a letter to his mother, 18 year-old Hugh David, sub-lieutenant on the battleship HMS Revenge, recounts the sight of "Carley floats, chairs and human beings" in the wreckage. He describes it as "the grimmest and most pathetic incident of the whole war".

synopses.long: A 24-year-old woman has died after a rock fell on her head on a beach in south Wales.

synopses.long: The night-time chimes of Llangollen Town Hall's clock should be silenced so people can get a good night's sleep, a hotelier has said.

clip.title: Elephant poo points to poaching hotspots

synopses.short: DNA from seized ivory and elephant poo helps target poaching hotspots in Africa
synopses.medium: DNA from seized ivory and elephant poo helps target poaching hotspots in Africa
synopses.long: Elephant poaching is on the rise. Worst hit is the African elephant – with 51,000 reportedly killed for their ivory in 2013. New research in the journal Science this week has shown that the poaching is not localised and scattered throughout Africa. But rather concentrated in two main hotspots. Conservation Biologist, Dr Sam Wasser, at the University of Washington in the US, came to these conclusions after analysing the DNA in the seized ivory, and then matching it to elephant material found in their dung, to tie the elephant’s origin back to one particular place. (Photo caption: A poached elephant lies in the Mozambican bush after being shot dead by poacher gunfire © Alastair Nelson/Wildlife Conservation Society via AP)

clip.title: Causes of suicide are complex, says Samaritans Wales boss

synopses.short: 'Causes of suicide are complex'
synopses.medium: Causes of suicide are complex, says Samaritans Wales boss Sarah Stone
synopses.long: The suicide rate for men in Wales is at its highest since 1981, with a 23% rise between 2012 and 2013, the Samaritans says.

clip.title: How Britain Fell in Love with Tea

synopses.short: Dan explores the story of how the country became a nation of tea drinkers.
synopses.medium: Dan joins historian Markman Ellis and tea expert Angela Pryce to find out how the country became a nation of tea drinkers
synopses.long: The story of how an expensive habit of the upper classes, became a drink embraced by all of British society. Dan meets historian Markman Ellis at Britain's most famous tea clipper ship, the Cutty Sark. And he sits down for a cup of tea with expert Angela Pryce. (Photo: cup of tea. Credit: Jamais_vu/Thinkstock)

clip.title: 'Before the idea of religion came, yoga was'

synopses.short: Sadhguru Jaggi Vasudev on claims Hindu nationalists are exploiting yoga
synopses.medium: Sadhguru Jaggi Vasudev dismissed claims yoga is being exploited by Hindu nationalists.
synopses.long: This Sunday India is marking the first International Day of Yoga with what it boasts will be the biggest yoga session ever. More than 35,000 people are expected to turn out to tie themselves in knots on the vast ceremonial lawns outside the Indian parliament. "Yoga is about turning your system for a higher level of perception, a larger slice of life," Sadhguru Jaggi Vasudev told Today. He dismissed claims Prime Minister Narendra Modi was using yoga as part of a Hindu nationalist agenda. "Yoga predates all religion," said Jaggi Vasudev. "Before the idea of religion came, yoga was." The leading yogi was speaking to BBC South Asia correspondent Justin Rowlatt in possibly the most stressful radio interview ever broadcast - for our correspondent's body at least.

clip.title: Charleston Reverend: Black church shooting inevitable

synopses.short: Charleston Reverend says there must be frank discussions over race after church shooting.
synopses.medium: Charleston Reverend says 'there is racist rancour in America'. Joseph Darby says there must be frank discussions over race following deadly African-American church shooting.
synopses.long: Charleston Reverend calls for frank discussions over race in America after deadly church shooting. Reverend Joseph Darby says 'It was just a matter of time before someone decided to shoot up a black church'. He told Nomia Iqbal 'There is racist rancour' in America. Nine people were shot dead in the Emanuel Methodist Church on Wednesday night during a prayer meeting. This clip is originally from Up All Night on Friday 19 June 2015

clip.title: "We Forgive Him for What He's Done"

synopses.short: Children of Charleston shooting victim, Sharonda Singleton, say they forgive her killer
synopses.medium: Children of Charleston shooting victim, Sharonda Singleton, say they forgive her killer
synopses.long: Chris and Camryn, the children of Sharonda Singleton, one of those killed in the Charleston church shooting say they already forgive their Mother's killer. They have been speaking to the BBC's Rajini Vaidyanathan.

clip.title: Scientists Hopeful for New Malaria Drug

synopses.short: Scientists are extremely hopeful a new drug will work against drug-resistant Malaria
synopses.medium: Scientists are extremely hopeful a new drug will work against drug-resistant Malaria
synopses.long: Scientists who have developed a new drug to treat malaria say they're extremely hopeful it will work against existing drug-resistant strains of the disease. The team say the drug has a completely new mechanism of action and will protect people from the disease and prevent it spreading, all in a single dose. However, they say development of the drug is at a very early stage and still has to undergo extensive testing. Professor Ian Gilbert was part of the research team. (Picture: A child suffering from malaria lies on a bed in a hospital in Tanzania / Credit: AFP/Getty Images)

clip.title: Iceland's Muslims Fasting Longest for Ramadan

synopses.short: For Ramadan, Iceland's Muslims will have the longest fast at twenty-two hours each day
synopses.medium: For Ramadan, Iceland's Muslims will have the longest fast at twenty-two hours each day
synopses.long: Thursday was the first day of Ramadan when Muslims around the world began fasting for a month, from sunrise until sunset. The long day in Iceland at this time of year means that Muslims there will have the longest fast in the world - at nearly twenty-two hours per day. Ahmad Taha Seddeeq is an Imam at the Islamic Cultural Centre in Iceland's capital Reykjavík. (Picture: The midnight sun in Iceland / Credit: Thinkstock)

clip.title: Castleford Tigers 25-24 St Helens: Match highlights + Daryl Powell & Jake Webster reaction

synopses.short: Highlights + post-match reaction as Castleford beat St Helens in a Super League thriller.

clip.title: The Man Challenging Uganda's Museveni

synopses.short: Uganda's former Prime Minister Amama Mbabazi hopes to become the country's next President
synopses.medium: Uganda's former Prime Minister Amama Mbabazi hopes to become the country's next President
synopses.long: Uganda's former Prime Minister Amama Mbabazi is challenging his long-time ally President Yoweri Museveni to become the next president in 2016. Mr Mbabazi said he will first seek the nomination to become the candidate for the governing National Resistance Movement party. Newsday's Alan Kasujja caught up with Mr Mbabazi and asked him had he discussed his plans with President Museveni. (Picture: Amama Mbabazi with Alan Kasujja / Credit: BBC)

clip.title: Guzzy Bear v Bobby Friction

synopses.short: Comedian Guzzy Bear drops in to talk about his short film Roadman Ramadan
synopses.medium: Guzzy Bear, viral comedian, drops into the Big Desi Show to chat about his first day fasting and his new short film Roadman Ramadan
synopses.long: Comedian Guzzy Bear drops into the Big Desi Show to chat about his first day fasting, his new short film, Roadman Ramadan and his video about Pakistani dinosaurs, which he made after watching Jurassic World, that went viralviral

clip.title: Lynsey Sharp: I was forced to wait in a cafe for a drugs test

synopses.short: The athlete explains why being available for a drugs test is not as easy as it sounds.
synopses.medium: Commonwealth 800m silver medallist Lyndsey Sharp explains why being available for a drugs test is not as easy as it sounds.
synopses.long: Commonwealth 800m silver medallist Lyndsey Sharp explains why being available for a drugs test is not as easy as it sounds. Sharp was speaking to Eleanor Oldroyd following claims by the Daily Mail that Mo Farah missed two drugs tests prior to his double gold medal-winning performance at the 2012 Olympics. The Mail says the second one came at Farah's home in February 2011, when he claimed not to have heard the doorbell. Sharp revealed that she encountered a doorbell problem of her own during a recent training camp in Boston. "I rented an apartment and checking it had a doorbell wasn't top of my list... It had no doorbell so I had to make my (pre-arranged) available slot each day in a cafe at the end of the road". This clip is originally from 5 live Sport on Thursday 18 June 2015.

clip.title: Philae lander, which has Essex-made equipment on board, wakes up

synopses.short: Chelmsford-based e2v engineer has latest on the Philae lander after its months of silence
synopses.medium: Chelmsford-based e2v engineer has latest on the Philae lander after its months of silence
synopses.long: Paul Jerram, Head of Engineering Sensors at e2v in Chelmsford, which has some of its imaging sensor technology on board the Philae lander, which made history when it landed on a comet in November 2014, tells BBC Essex presenter, Mark Matthews, that many people were surprised that the probe has sprung back into life after seven months of silence. Paul also discusses a NASA mission to Pluto that e2v has supplied imaging sensors for. New Horizons comes to fruition on July 14th after a nine year journey through the solar system. It will take the most detailed photographs of the icy planet's surface to date whilst travelling at speeds of 30,000 mph.

clip.title: Alan Dedicoat reads the new lottery numbers

synopses.short: A world exclusive. Alan Dedicoat, the voice of the balls, reads the numbers from 50 to 59
synopses.medium: A world exclusive. Alan Dedicoat, the voice of the balls, reads the numbers from 50 to 59
synopses.long: A world exclusive. Alan Dedicoat, the voice of the balls, reads the numbers from 50 to 59

clip.title: Job seekers in Greece: 'It's difficult to find a job'

synopses.short: A woman searching for employment in Athens says "it's very difficult to find a job".
synopses.medium: A woman searching for employment at a job centre in Athens says "it's very difficult to find a job".
synopses.long: A woman searching for employment at a job centre in Athens says "it's very difficult to find a job". In 2014, Greece had the highest unemployment in Europe at 26.5 per cent. "I was working at the insurance works," said Elizabeth, who lost her job in the economic crisis. "Now it's very difficult to find a job because I'm very old. I'm 43. Employers don't take old people to work because we have children and it's difficult. " "I don't think anything [agreement with International Monetary Fund] is going to happen. We have a very big problem," she added. This clip is originally from 5 live Drive on Thursday 18 June 2015.

clip.title: Tim Whewell on the trail of Moldova’s missing millions

synopses.short: Tim Whewell on the trail of Moldova’s missing millions
synopses.medium: Tim Whewell on the trail of Moldova’s missing millions
synopses.long: Protesters on the streets of Moldova want to see people put behind bars after a billion dollars was apparently stolen from their banks. The black hole left in the economy - equivalent to half the government's annual revenue - will ultimately be filled from the pockets of ordinary taxpayers after the banks were bailed out. So how do you steal a billion dollars from Europe's poorest country? Tim Whewell has been on the trail of Moldova's missing millions. (Photo: Ilan Shor ran a successful mayoral election campaign despite the accusation that he’s behind the missing money. BBC Copyright)

episode.title: The Mysterious Magnate and Moldova’s Missing Millions

synopses.long: Paul Bley was one of Ornette Coleman’s key early collaborators, recording Live at the Hillcrest with him in 1958. Here, he reflects on the impact of playing with Coleman.

synopses.medium: Ford on Surrey's loss v Glamorgan

clip.title: Safe spaces for a global black diaspora

synopses.short: British filmmaker Cecile Emeke speaks to BBC's Ruchi Tandon.
synopses.medium: British filmmaker Cecile Emeke speaks to BBC's Ruchi Tandon.
synopses.long: “Safe spaces for a global black diaspora”, just some of the things British filmmaker and artist Cecile Emeke has been talking about. She has created her own YouTube channel to give a platform to black voices, and her web series and films have been gaining popularity across the world. For her series Strolling, she walks and talks with people about the issues affecting them, everything from identity, to the gentrification of parts of London and more. The series started with black British stories and experiences, and now she has filmed episodes in France and there are plans to take the idea to other countries as well. So is there a need for safe spaces and more platforms for black voices today? In this extract BBC UK Black’s Ruchi Tandon speaks to Cecile Emeke. This interview includes audio from the Strolling series.

clip.title: Ramadan 2015 Q&A

synopses.short: Imam Yunus Dudhwala answers your questions about fasting
synopses.medium: Imam Yunus Dudhwala answers your questions about fasting
synopses.long: Are you diabetic? Will you be fasting? It is not a simple yes or no answer unfortunately. For people who suffer from any health conditions, Ramadan can be extremely tough. Do you think there is enough awareness about fasting during Ramadan if you are diabetic or suffer from any other illness? Is there pressure on you to fast in spite of your condition? Who do you turn to if you're stuck in that dilemma - you are religious, you do want to fast, but you have a health condition, what do you do in a situation like that? Imam Yunis Dudhwala is on hand to answer some of your Ramadan questions.

clip.title: Music from the Streets of Kinshasa

synopses.short: Mbongwana Star is a new band from DR Congo mixing traditional rhythms and post punk sounds
synopses.medium: Mbongwana Star is a new band from the Democratic Republic of Congo that mixes traditional rhythms and post punk sounds
synopses.long: Mbongwana Star is a new band from the Democratic Republic of Congo that mixes traditional rhythms and post punk sounds. The band is formed of five Congolese musicians and produced by the French-Irish DJ Liam Farrell, also known as Doctor L. Singer Theo Nzonza and Doctor L speak about how their unusual band got together. (Picture: Mbongwana Star Credit: Florent de La Tullaye)

clip.title: Why do we love Jane Eyre?

synopses.short: Melvyn Bragg and guests discuss one of the best-known novels in British fiction
synopses.medium: Melvyn Bragg and guests discuss one of the best-known novels in British fiction
synopses.long: When Jane Eyre was published in 1847, it was a great success, it brought fame to Charlotte Brontë and is regarded as one of the best-known novels in British fiction. But why? Melvyn Bragg is joined by Dinah Birch, Professor of English Literature and Pro-Vice-Chancellor for Research at the University of Liverpool and Karen O'Brien, Vice Principal and Professor of English Literature at King's College London. First broadcast on In Our Time, 18 June 2015.

synopses.medium: Historian Robert Greene on Charleston church shooting.
synopses.long: Nine people have been shot dead at the historic Emanuel AME church in Charleston, South Carolina. Historian Robert Greene explains why the church is so significant for African Americans and what the attack means to him. (Photo credit: AP Photo/David Goldman)

clip.title: Energy Secretary: I wouldn't want wind farm 'behind my house'

synopses.short: MP Amber Rudd on cutting onshore wind farm budgets.
synopses.medium: MP Amber Rudd on cutting onshore wind farm budgets.
synopses.long: Secretary of State for Energy and Climate Change has said onshore wind farms "have gone far enough" as the government cuts funds. Amber Rudd said, "we have to use our precious bill payer's to support a variety of renewable energy supplies" and feels enough money is being spent on onshore wind. It is estimated that 3,000 wind turbines are awaiting planning permission as the decision to cut subsidies has been made. She added, "i'm not against wind farms per se, but I probably wouldn't want it in the field behind my house". This clip is originally from 5 live Breakfast on June 18 2015.

clip.title: Training Rats to Detect Landmines

synopses.short: Bart Weetjens devised a way to use giant rats to sniff out landmines
synopses.medium: Bart Weetjens devised a way to use giant rats to sniff out landmines
synopses.long: Twenty years ago Bart Weetjens combined a life-long passion for rodents with a desire to help African countries blighted by discarded weapons of war. His charity has used specially trained rats to clear over forty eight thousand landmines and other unexploded ordnance in five countries around the world. Now they've come up with another novel use for the rats' skills - this time in diagnosing tuberculosis. (Picture: Bart Weetjens with Chavez, one of his trained rats Picture credit: APOPO)

filter.name: audio_described
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes that are audio-described

option.title: filter for programmes that are audio-described
filter for programmes that are not audio-described

filter.name: availability
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes that have availability

option.title: filter for programmes that are expected to become available imminently

filter.name: availability
filter.title: filter for programmes that will become available within given duration

filter.name: availability_from
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes that are available after or at the specified datetime

filter.name: availability_to
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes that are available before the specified datetime

filter.name: children_of
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes that have PID as immediate parent

filter.name: descendants_of
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes that have PID as ancestor

filter.name: duration
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes that have given duration

option.title: filter for programmes that have short duration (< 5m)
filter for programmes that have medium duration (5m - 30m)
filter for programmes that have long duration (> 30m)

filter.name: entity_type
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes that have given entity type

option.title: filter for programmes that are brands
filter for programmes that are series
filter for programmes that are episodes

filter.name: format
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes with format

filter.name: genre
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes with genre

filter.name: group
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes which belong to the given group pid

filter.name: initial_letter
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes with title beginning with initial letter librarian style (ignoring leading 'The', 'An' (Welsh), etc) 0-9 a-z

filter.name: initial_letter_end
filter.title: Programmes with (librarian) titles whose initial letter is equal/before given letter. Use with initial_letter_start for a range

filter.name: initial_letter_start
filter.title: Programmes with (librarian) titles whose initial letter is equal/after given letter. Use with initial_letter_end for range.

filter.name: initial_letter_stop
filter.title: Programmes with (librarian) titles whose initial letter is equal/before given letter. Use with initial_letter_start for a range

filter.name: initial_letter_strict
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes with title beginning with initial letter

filter.name: item
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes with linked to versions which have the given item pids

filter.name: master_brand
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes with master_brand

filter.name: media_set
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes with media set

filter.name: partner_id
filter.title: filter for programmes by partner ID

filter.name: partner_pid
filter.title: filter for programmes by partner PID

filter.name: people
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes with contributions by given people PID

filter.name: pid
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes having given PID

filter.name: promoted_for
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes which are promoted for given service

filter.name: q
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes matching supplied keyword/phrase (boolean operators permitted)

filter.name: signed
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes that are signed

option.title: filter for programmes that are signed
filter for programmes regardless of signedness
filter for programmes that are not signed

filter.name: tag_name
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes with tag

filter.name: tag_scheme
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes with a tag

filter.name: tleo
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes that are TLEOs

option.title: filter for programmes that are TLEOs
filter for programmes that are not TLEOs

filter.name: version
filter.title: filter for subset of programmes with given PID as one of their versions

sort.name: group_position
sort.title: sort numerically by position in group, ascending

sort.name: most_popular
sort.title: sort numerically by popularity (most popular first)

sort.name: release_date
sort.title: sort chronologically by release date, descending

sort.name: relevance
sort.title: sort by weighting of search term (use with q parameter)

sort.name: scheduled_start
sort.title: sort chronologically by scheduled start time/date, ascending

sort.name: title
sort.title: sort by title librarian style (ignoring leading 'The', 'A', etc), ascending

sort.name: tree
sort.title: sort by root pid and then preorder tree sort. Requires entities to have release date.

sort.name: views
sort.title: sort numerically by number of views (most popular first - faster most_popular)

mixin.name: contributions
mixin.title: mixin to return information about contributors to a programme

mixin.name: duration
mixin.title: mixin to return original version duration in programme concept entities

mixin.name: images

mixin.name: is_embeddable

mixin.name: people
mixin.title: mixin to return information about contributors to a programme

mixin.name: related_links
mixin.title: mixin to return information about related links to a programme

mixin.name: titles
